At our Spring Conference this weekend, members will be debating a motion empowering public sector workers. 

We have always been the strongest supporters of localism and we believe it's time for the birdcage to be unlocked and our public sector staff set free to respond directly to local communities and the situation on the ground. 

It takes ten years to train a GP. It takes four years to train a nurse or a teacher. And it takes two years to train a police officer.

Yet Ministers sitting in government towers like to think they know best. Do they know how to treat patients better than nurses and doctors? Or how to prevent crime in our communities better than police? Or how to teach children better than teachers?

The SNP's target culture has heaped more and more pressure onto our public services and morale has hit rock bottom.

By protecting workers who whistle blow on risky practices, we will be protecting Scottish communities and promoting transparency. And by creating the post of a Minister for Public Workforce Empowerment we will enshrine empowerment across all levels of government and reduce form-filling for staff.

The SNP's one-size-fits-all policies have restricted the potential of those who provide our public services up and down the country. It's time to liberate them from the government's straightjackets.

Today Alison McInnes MSP has set out our plans to prevent ineffective short-term prison sentences.

A presumption against prison sentences of three months or less was introduced in Scotland in 2010. As part of our manifesto proposals for the Holyrood elections in May, Liberal Democrats will put forward an extension of the presumption to cover sentences of 12 months or less.

59% of offenders given jail sentences of three months or less reoffend with one year. Reconviction rates for people given a community sentence are more than 10% lower than those released from prison.
